document_data.name: ''Old Sailors' Chant of the Sword Coast''
document_data.author: [[Hamlaer Dunther]]
document_data.mainbody:
The '''''Old Sailors' Chant of the Sword Coast''''' was a folk sea shanty, recorded by Way-Minstrel [[Hamlaer Dunther]] in the late 14{{th}} century [[DR]]. {{quote|''But when the storm clouds gather and grow dark
And the wind rises high and starts to scream
Find snug harbor in haste and take cover, for in the end
Heavy weather topples even the mightiest keeps.''|An expert from the ''Old Sailors' Chant.''}}
document_data.History: The ''Old Sailors' Chant'' was a sea shanty written by the good sea-fairing folk of the [[Sword Coast]] some time in or before the 14{{th}} century DR. Hamlaer Dunther, Way-Minstrel, recorded the song along with other folk ballads in his [[book]] titled ''[[Ballads of the People]]'', published in the {{YearlinkName|1376}}.
